awd_titl_txt: Diálogos: Harnessing Latinx Community Cultural Wealth to Support Executive Function in Early Childhood through Family Engineering Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

It has been well documented that under-resourced Latinx communities face persistent barriers to accessing quality STEM education and STEM careers, particularly in the field of engineering. For young children and their families from these communities, the development of executive function skills offers promising pathways to support educational success and prepare children to engage with STEM practices and content. Executive function skills, such as focusing attention, retaining information, and managing emotions are critical for children’s development and long-term success, and have been identified as central to engagement with STEM practices and content, whether in or out of school. However, much of the work on development of executive function skills to date has been conducted with White, middle-class children and has largely ignored the knowledge, values, or perspectives of other communities, including Latinx families. Similar gaps also exist in attention to culturally responsive approaches to using family-based STEM activities to support executive function skills. Taken together, there is a critical need to work with Latinx communities to re-imagine the intersection of STEM learning and executive function skills using equity-based frameworks. This Pilot and Feasibility project will develop and test a new participatory, dialogic method that leverages informal family engineering activities to support the development of executive function skills for preschool-age children from Latinx families. The combination of this proposal’s unique engagement of parents as research partners with the study of engineering and executive functions could lay the foundation for a promising program of future equity-focused research.

Three research questions will guide the study: 1) What knowledge, assets, and practices already exist within Latinx families related to these executive function skills? 2) What aspects of executive function skills can be supported through informal family engineering activities? and 3) What are promising design strategies for adapting informal family engineering activities to highlight family assets and support executive function skills for young children? To address these questions, the project team will engage Latinx parents in a dialogue series in which parents are central collaborators, sharing their in-depth perspectives and partnering with researchers to develop conceptual frameworks and new approaches. Data generated through these ongoing discussions will be analyzed using (a) qualitative, participatory approaches, including iterative co-development and refinement of emergent themes with parents, (b) detailed inductive coding of parent dialogue group discussions using grounded theory techniques, and (c) retrospective analysis at the end of the project. The parent dialogue series will be supported by a systematic literature review examining the intersections between engineering design, executive function, and the strengths and assets within Latinx families. The results of the exploratory research will include a (1)  conceptual framework co-developed with parents that highlights promising opportunities and design strategies for using family engineering design activities to support executive function skills for preschool-age children from Latinx families and (2) research agenda outlining questions and priorities for future work that reflect the goals and interests of this community. Aligned with project’s equity approach, the team will work collaboratively with project partners and families for dissemination, focusing on amplifying community voices, sharing challenges and successes, and supporting improvements in the local community. Results will also be broadly shared with educators and researchers to advance knowledge and promote new equitable approaches to collaborating with parents from Latinx communities.

This Pilots and Feasibility project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to (a) advance new approaches to and evidence-based understanding of the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments; (b) provide multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences; (c) advance innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments; and (d) engage the public of all ages in learning STEM in informal environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

Diálogos was a two-year NSF AISL Pilot and Feasibility project focused on collaborating with low-income Latinx families with preschool-age children (3 to 5 years) to explore how informal engineering-focused family activities can support young children's executive function (EF) skills in engaging, culturally relevant, and strength-based ways. Executive function skills, which include cognitive flexibility, working memory, and self-regulation, are critical for early learning and foundational for success in STEM and life. The project aimed to explore these skills through engineering activities, situating them within the lived experiences and cultural values of Latinx families. Through the development, implementation, and research of a collaborative dialogue family engagement model, the project explored how Latinx families perceive and value engineering and EF, the strengths and assets they bring to these topics, and the different culturally relevant approaches they may use to support their children's engineering engagement and EF development.

The project was a partnership between TERC, Oregon State University, Metropolitan Family Service (MFS), and Mount Hood Community College Head Start (MHCC HS). Twelve Latinx families enrolled in local early childhood programs played an integral role in the project, participating in the dialogue groups, co-developing and testing engineering activities and resources, and most importantly contributing their cultural knowledge, lived experiences, and leadership to shape the model and outcomes. Conducted entirely in Spanish and with a mostly bilingual and bicultural leadership team, the dialogue groups entered equity by positioning families as co-creators in their children's educational journey.

Key Outcomes

1. Development of the Dialogue Group Model

A critical outcome of the project was the development and implementation of the dialogue groups as a family engagement model. This model included facilitated conversations between caregivers and the project team and employed a variety of design strategies to build community among caregivers, highlight and celebrate the strengths and assets of Latinx families, and explore connections with engineering and EF. Across the dialogue groups, caregivers shared their goals related to their children's learning and development, tested activities at home, and shared reflections and stories about their values, goals, and dreams for their children. Discussions often centered on how engineering activities could help children become flexible and creative problem-solvers and support family relationships.

The research component of the project showed that the dialogue group model provides a unique context for the identification and exploration of educational challenges and interventions. The project demonstrated that families can collaborate with educators and researchers in productive ways that center caregivers' goals, interests, and values. The families that participated in the project talked about four focus areas that can impact the ways we approach STEM learning and EF skill development: (a) supporting collaboration and relationships within families, (b) supporting children as problems solvers, (c) supporting parents as learners, and (d) creating a community of support.

2. Family Resilience Framework

Another important outcome of the project was the adaptation of Walsh’s Family Resilience Framework to describe different components of resilience as cultural assets for Latinx families and the ways these relate to engineering and EF. Through the dialogue groups, families shared a variety of stories that highlighted resilience and adaptability as essential life skills that they want to teach children as part of fostering early learning and development. Through the research, the project team was able to describe key aspects that support resiliency for families, such as connectedness, resourcefulness, and flexibility. The knowledge generated through the project about family resiliency is directly relevant to educational practice, especially as it relates to the development of STEM learning programs. For example, families shared that they value STEM learning opportunities that are framed around real-life scenarios and culturally relevant contexts. They also appreciate and are actively searching for opportunities that benefit their children, especially that support children's adaptability, openness, and flexibility. Engineering activities in particular can support these aspects of resilience because they help children and families practice problem-solving in everyday situations. 

Broader Impacts

Diálogos demonstrated the transformative potential of family-centered approaches to equitable STEM education. By positioning families as co-creators, the project advanced a model for culturally relevant early STEM learning that prioritizes community voices and values. This adaptable model has broader applications across disciplines and contexts, offering a framework for future family engagement initiatives. Currently, the Diálogos team is applying the model to explore equitable math learning with caregivers and early childhood educators. Early findings suggest that the approach's emphasis on cultural relevance, collaboration, and community-building holds promise across STEM domains.

Beyond research, the project's findings have implications for policy and practice. The team has disseminated the knowledge and resources generated in Diálogos with researchers, early childhood practitioners, and parent leaders and educators highlighting the importance of supporting families as key stakeholders in early STEM education. These efforts provide actionable insights for designing programs that align with families’ goals and strengths.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2024
Modified by: Smirla Ramos-Montanez
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Overview


Dilogos was a two-year NSF AISL Pilot and Feasibility project focused on collaborating with low-income Latinx families with preschool-age children (3 to 5 years) to explore how informal engineering-focused family activities can support young children's executive function (EF) skills in engaging, culturally relevant, and strength-based ways. Executive function skills, which include cognitive flexibility, working memory, and self-regulation, are critical for early learning and foundational for success in STEM and life. The project aimed to explore these skills through engineering activities, situating them within the lived experiences and cultural values of Latinx families. Through the development, implementation, and research of a collaborative dialogue family engagement model, the project explored how Latinx families perceive and value engineering and EF, the strengths and assets they bring to these topics, and the different culturally relevant approaches they may use to support their children's engineering engagement and EF development.


The project was a partnership between TERC, Oregon State University, Metropolitan Family Service (MFS), and Mount Hood Community College Head Start (MHCC HS). Twelve Latinx families enrolled in local early childhood programs played an integral role in the project, participating in the dialogue groups, co-developing and testing engineering activities and resources, and most importantly contributing their cultural knowledge, lived experiences, and leadership to shape the model and outcomes. Conducted entirely in Spanish and with a mostly bilingual and bicultural leadership team, the dialogue groups entered equity by positioning families as co-creators in their children's educational journey.

1. Development of the Dialogue Group Model


A critical outcome of the project was the development and implementation of the dialogue groups as a family engagement model. This model included facilitated conversations between caregivers and the project team and employed a variety of design strategies to build community among caregivers, highlight and celebrate the strengths and assets of Latinx families, and explore connections with engineering and EF. Across the dialogue groups, caregivers shared their goals related to their children's learning and development, tested activities at home, and shared reflections and stories about their values, goals, and dreams for their children. Discussions often centered on how engineering activities could help children become flexible and creative problem-solvers and support family relationships.


The research component of the project showed that the dialogue group model provides a unique context for the identification and exploration of educational challenges and interventions. The project demonstrated that families can collaborate with educators and researchers in productive ways that center caregivers' goals, interests, and values. The families that participated in the project talked about four focus areas that can impact the ways we approach STEM learning and EF skill development: (a) supporting collaboration and relationships within families, (b) supporting children as problems solvers, (c) supporting parents as learners, and (d) creating a community of support.


2. Family Resilience Framework


Another important outcome of the project was the adaptation of Walshs Family Resilience Framework to describe different components of resilience as cultural assets for Latinx families and the ways these relate to engineering and EF. Through the dialogue groups, families shared a variety of stories that highlighted resilience and adaptability as essential life skills that they want to teach children as part of fostering early learning and development. Through the research, the project team was able to describe key aspects that support resiliency for families, such as connectedness, resourcefulness, and flexibility. The knowledge generated through the project about family resiliency is directly relevant to educational practice, especially as it relates to the development of STEM learning programs. For example, families shared that they value STEM learning opportunities that are framed around real-life scenarios and culturally relevant contexts. They also appreciate and are actively searching for opportunities that benefit their children, especially that support children's adaptability, openness, and flexibility. Engineering activities in particular can support these aspects of resilience because they help children and families practice problem-solving in everyday situations.


Broader Impacts


Dilogos demonstrated the transformative potential of family-centered approaches to equitable STEM education. By positioning families as co-creators, the project advanced a model for culturally relevant early STEM learning that prioritizes community voices and values. This adaptable model has broader applications across disciplines and contexts, offering a framework for future family engagement initiatives. Currently, the Dilogos team is applying the model to explore equitable math learning with caregivers and early childhood educators. Early findings suggest that the approach's emphasis on cultural relevance, collaboration, and community-building holds promise across STEM domains.


Beyond research, the project's findings have implications for policy and practice. The team has disseminated the knowledge and resources generated in Dilogos with researchers, early childhood practitioners, and parent leaders and educators highlighting the importance of supporting families as key stakeholders in early STEM education. These efforts provide actionable insights for designing programs that align with families goals and strengths.
